<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Felectric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas%2Four%20insights%2Fputting%20renewable%20energy%20within%20reach%20vietnams%20high%20stakes%20pivot%2Fputting-renewable-energy-within-reach-vietnams-high-stakes-pivot.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="putting-renewable-energy-within-reach-vietnams-high-stakes-pivot" data-layer-report-name="putting-renewable-energy-within-reach-vietnams-high-stakes-pivot>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (11 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Vietnam’s long-awaited</strong> Power Development Plan VIII (PDP8) has recently been approved, setting ambitious renewable-energy goals for 2030—similar to the recommendations for Vietnam to embrace renewables set out in our 2019 article, “<a href="/featured-insights/asia-pacific/exploring-an-alternative-pathway-for-vietnams-energy-future">Exploring an alternative pathway for Vietnam’s energy future</a>.” These goals are focused on boosting renewable energy while reducing the country’s reliance on coal. This presents Vietnam with a conundrum: its renewable-energy projects are not consistently bankable at present, held back by regulations and the market.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This article is a collaborative effort by Jonathan Deffarges, <a href="/our-people/bruce-delteil">Bruce Delteil</a>, Takuya Hata, Van Pham, <a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b42fb84cb-b8db-4f40-b137-e2e4cf90c8c1%7d%40en">Suvojoy Sengupta</a>, Kunal Tara, and Hang Vu, representing views from McKinsey’s Electric Power & Natural Gas Practice.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>However, current market conditions present the country’s energy sector with a unique opportunity. Many manufacturers are avoiding investing solely in China by diversifying into neighboring countries to mitigate geopolitical risk, including into Vietnam.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8363237a-af27-4655-9ba5-4b79f60b3519"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8363237a-af27-4655-9ba5-4b79f60b3519" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Gartner survey reveals 33% of supply chain leaders moved business out of China or plan to by 2023,” Gartner, June 24, 2020; Doug Donahue, “Subcontract manufacturers in China: The risks and alternative options,” <em>Forbes</em>, June 18, 2021; Orla Ryan, “Vietnam becomes vital link in supply chain as business pivots from China,” <em>Financial Times</em>, July 2, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> To support this trend of incoming foreign direct investment (FDI), Vietnam could deploy more renewables to meet commercial and industrial (C&I) customers’ increasing demand for renewables.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="372d4bc6-7004-4a77-a00a-61b727bb970c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="372d4bc6-7004-4a77-a00a-61b727bb970c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Vietnam’s manufacturing future rests on a credible renewable energy game plan,” Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis, May 10, 2022; “Renewable energy policy needs to build momentum,” <em>Vietnam Investment Review</em>, April 20, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> If it can seize this opportunity and successfully address the challenges that arise, Vietnam has the potential to become a regional champion for both installed renewable capacity and sustainable manufacturing.</p>
<p>In part through the PDP8’s boost for renewable energy, Vietnam has committed to net zero by 2050 and, to achieve this, should rapidly increase its renewable-energy mix to decarbonize the power sector by around 78 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e2366ad2-5d8b-452b-b5b9-a55aa52542d9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e2366ad2-5d8b-452b-b5b9-a55aa52542d9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Efforts to implement Vietnam’s commitments at COP26,” “Ministry of Industry and Trade of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, July 15, 2022; McKinsey Decarbonization Scenario Model, Vietnam.</span></span></span></a></span> Fortunately, Vietnam has huge renewable-energy potential, as it is the most naturally suited country in Southeast Asia to <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/charting-a-path-for-vietnam-to-achieve-its-net-zero-goals">develop wind and solar energy</a>, with the technical potential of 1,000 gigawatts (GW) (Exhibit 1). This immense opportunity for renewables capacity was explored in the <a href="/featured-insights/asia-pacific/exploring-an-alternative-pathway-for-vietnams-energy-future">2019 article</a> previously mentioned.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/putting%20renewable%20energy%20within%20reach%20vietnams%20high%20stakes%20pivot/svgz-vietnamnetzero-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Vietnam has natural endowments with high potential for wind and solar power." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/putting%20renewable%20energy%20within%20reach%20vietnams%20high%20stakes%20pivot/svgz-vietnamnetzero-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Yet, after an initial wave of (mostly solar) projects driven by favorable feed-in tariffs (FiTs), current renewable-energy projects are no longer consistently economically viable. Unless this situation changes, Vietnam’s net-zero ambitions—as well as the PDP8’s goals—are at risk, with market and regulatory constraints preventing this potential from being realized (Exhibit 2). Consider also that Vietnam’s neighbors might develop renewable energy faster, attracting international 100 percent renewable-energy (RE100) manufacturers at Vietnam’s expense. The time to ramp up renewable-energy production is now—for the business opportunity as well as the country’s sustainability.</p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Our methodology</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>There are many paths</strong> to achieving economic 50 or 100 percent renewable energy (RE50/RE100) in specific contexts and use cases in Vietnam by 2030. We use RE100 as a target, given that many commercial and industrial customers (for example, the companies in the RE100 global initiative) are demanding 24/7 renewable power.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e846c7a6-22d9-4f75-898c-2189180d2045"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e846c7a6-22d9-4f75-898c-2189180d2045" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“How RE100 members are going ‘beyond 100%’ in the US,” Climate Group, January 28, 2021; “Frequently asked questions (FAQ): Technical, RE100,” Climate Group, April 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> This article outlines particular steps that we believe could be the most impactful and that are feasible from a technology and supply chain perspective in aggregate, based on current outlooks.</p>
<p>To arrive at this pathway, we used proprietary optimization models and data from McKinsey’s Green Power Procurement Optimizer tool, Hydrogen Insights, and the Strategy & Corporate Finance Practice to evaluate about 100 cost-reduction levers to minimize Vietnam’s overall cost of electricity generation. In this optimization, we accounted for national and regional constraints such as (but not exclusively) technical maximum for wind- and solar-power generation, maximum pumped hydro-energy storage potential in each province, land availability for renewable-energy sites, and planned renewable-energy capacity for each technology in Vietnam’s Power Development Plan VIII.</p>
<p>We did not account for the nonmonetary benefits achieved by RE50/RE100, such as reduced air pollution, greater health benefits, and reduced physical climate risks through decarbonization. These benefits are significant for Vietnam.</p>
<p>This outcome is not a forecast but rather a road map that illustrates how national ministries, provinces, and corporate stakeholders could collaborate across different sectors to decrease the cost of electricity by 2030 and increase penetration of renewables.</p>
<p>We consider the exploration of this road map to be valuable for two reasons: first, it demonstrates that Vietnam has the potential to deploy renewables at a greater scale—economically—than it currently does, and second, the road map lays out specific steps that public- and private-sector stakeholders could take to make this happen.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>How can Vietnam achieve this? It needs to invest in, build, and integrate more solar and wind power to allow the country to provide 50 or 100 percent renewable energy (RE50/RE100) in an economically viable way—thus making it more attractive to manufacturers, investors, and renewable-energy developers. In this article, we focus on feasible steps that energy stakeholders could take to achieve this goal and highlight how collaboration between the public and private sectors could help accelerate renewable-energy development (see sidebar, “Our methodology”).</p>
<h2>Vietnam’s pivot to renewables: Embracing the path to leadership in sustainability</h2>
<p>If Vietnam cannot transition to renewables soon, it will likely face significant risks to its energy security, growth and development, and current economic base, as well as physical hazards from climate change—this could come at Vietnam’s expense while its neighbors prosper. The risks, as described below, raise the stakes for the urgent deployment of renewables at scale.</p>
<h3>Energy insecurity and persistent blackouts</h3>
<p>With electricity demand increasing and extreme weather conditions affecting the country, renewable energy offers an independent source of energy security, not dependent on fossil-fuel imports. Recently, the country has faced electricity shortages and planned blackouts because of extreme heat, droughts, and hydropower plants reaching dangerously low water levels, for example, in industrial parks in northern provinces where large global manufacturers such as Samsung and Foxconn have facilities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b7a702ac-067b-484b-8e24-cbf07906e28f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b7a702ac-067b-484b-8e24-cbf07906e28f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Phan Hau, “Close-up of Northern hydropower reservoir running out of water for electricity generation, unprecedented drought,” Thanh Niên, June 8, 2023; Francesco Guarascio and Khanh Vu, “Vietnam’s power blackouts hit multinationals’ manufacturing hubs,” Reuters, June 5, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> As a result, the government has instituted rolling blackouts (sometimes unannounced) across the country—particularly in the north—that have affected citizens, tourism, and industrial parks.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="83316e2b-de42-400b-8d79-bb63e65674f4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="83316e2b-de42-400b-8d79-bb63e65674f4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Northern Vietnam’s unrelenting power outages explained,” <em>VnExpress</em>, June 9, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> This is happening while the country’s abundant natural endowments of wind and sunlight remain underutilized.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>Vietnam needs to unlock its renewable-energy development as quickly as possible to reach the government’s commitment to net zero by 2050 and the bold PDP8 goals, which aim for wind, solar, and other renewable sources (excluding hydropower) to cover at least 32 percent of the country’s energy needs by 2030.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="33f2377e-4244-44a8-a15a-06106e409004"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="33f2377e-4244-44a8-a15a-06106e409004" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Decision no. 896/QD-TTg on approving national strategy for climate change until 2050,” Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment, 2022; “Vietnam’s $135 billion power plan for 2030,” World Economic Forum, May 23, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Sources of growth and development abandoning Vietnam</h3>
<p>Many international companies are choosing Vietnam as they diversify from China, attracted by the country’s rapid economic growth and human capital abundance.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="51ec0b91-8e48-4c8c-9c71-e433fa509397"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="51ec0b91-8e48-4c8c-9c71-e433fa509397" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>IMF blog</em>, “Asia’s easing economic headwinds make way for stronger recovery,” blog post by Thomas Helberg, Shanaka T. Peiris, and Krishna Srinivasan, February 20, 2023; <em>PISA 2018 results</em>, OECD, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> However, Vietnam is at risk of losing these actors’ interest if it cannot meet their increased renewable-energy demands. Many of the world’s largest manufacturers have committed to 100 percent renewable energy for their operations (for example, those in the RE100 global initiative)<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b7717176-4a2d-479e-9e41-4d66bd6876b1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b7717176-4a2d-479e-9e41-4d66bd6876b1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“RE100 members: Over 400 RE100 companies have made a commitment to go ‘100% renewable,’” Climate Group RE100, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span>; these companies may not choose Vietnam if sufficient renewable power is not available. In addition, there are many global companies that don’t yet have existing operations in Vietnam—were it able to provide RE100, the country could potentially attract more investments.</p>
<h3>Risking Vietnam’s existing economic base</h3>
<p>If Vietnam does not implement renewables at scale now, it could jeopardize its current economic base, as manufacturers’ products face carbon tariffs without clean energy.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c3563a68-0080-4f95-814a-9e1d158b2ccb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c3563a68-0080-4f95-814a-9e1d158b2ccb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Exploring border carbon adjustments for Canada,” Government of Canada.</span></span></span></a></span> For example, more than $10 billion of Vietnam’s export turnover from industries under carbon border tax schemes might be impacted by 2030. If other countries implement similar taxes, around an additional $20 billion in exports from those industries could be impacted. And if other manufacturing products under the same regulations are included, this could further put at least $200 billion in exports at risk.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="27944995-0b8b-42fd-99f5-c1923f6b1946"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="27944995-0b8b-42fd-99f5-c1923f6b1946" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Regulation (EU) 2023/956,” May 10, 2023; “Exploring border carbon adjustments for Canada,” August 5, 2021; “Japan mulls over carbon border tax for polluters, Nikkei says,” February 11, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Physical hazards from climate change</h3>
<p>Vietnam faces significant physical risk from climate change. Urban areas especially are exposed—for example, the flood depth in Ho Chi Minh City could increase tenfold by 2050, and a 180 centimeter sea-level rise could put 66 percent of the city underwater. These climate change risks could cause 40 percent of the city to flood, and damage and associated losses could cost between $15 billion and $20 billion.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="eb5380e8-9972-46e8-ba8d-80f5e44107fa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="eb5380e8-9972-46e8-ba8d-80f5e44107fa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jack Board, “Extreme flood risk: New report outlines potentially disastrous scenario for Ho Chi Minh City,” <em>Channel News Asia</em>, May 17, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>If Vietnam doesn’t, its neighbors will</h3>
<p>Vietnam’s lagging renewable-energy projects stand in stark contrast to its neighbors that have already started to make renewable energy economical. For instance, India has targeted 500 GW renewable energy capacity by 2030 and introduced the Electricity Act in 2003 that paved the way for open access and corporate power purchase agreements (PPAs).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="06493c55-c7df-4828-9ca0-a5d17d48e1d2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="06493c55-c7df-4828-9ca0-a5d17d48e1d2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Corporate renewable PPAs in India: Market and policy update,” World Business Council for Sustainable Development, January 28, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Samsung is making India a smartphone manufacturing hub, and Foxconn is in discussion to launch a plant in Tamil Nadu.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="33e4201f-d107-4990-8cb7-86a913df8fa1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="33e4201f-d107-4990-8cb7-86a913df8fa1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Samsung eyes expansion, planning to make India smartphone manufacturing hub,” <em>Business Standard</em>, March 21, 2023; Praveen Paramasivam and Munsif Vengattil, “Foxconn unit in talks for $200 million component plant in Tamil Nadu,” Reuters, July 26, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>As another example, Malaysia has already launched virtual power purchase agreements (VPPAs) that have freed up consumers with more than 1 megawatt (MW) demand and has set targets for 70 percent renewables by 2050.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="14d0c477-1d33-420f-ab26-795614119a5a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="14d0c477-1d33-420f-ab26-795614119a5a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Malaysia sets new target to reach 70% of renewables in the power mix by 2050,” Enerdata, May 12, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> In contrast, at current tariffs in Vietnam, renewable-energy projects are often not consistently economical, and thus are viewed as unfavorable for developers.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="280cdf36-a7a1-42cd-b9ab-ccf3f151d743"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="280cdf36-a7a1-42cd-b9ab-ccf3f151d743" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Investors call for bankable PPA and reasonable price policies for energy projects,” <em>Vietnam Investment Review</em>, April 12, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> The country has not yet allowed direct power purchase  agreements (DPPAs) nor instituted mechanisms (including auction mechanisms) that would pave the way for renewable-energy projects. Vietnam’s higher energy price and low renewable-energy penetration could lead to a financial burden for consumers and a potential loss of foreign investment.</p>
<p>Then how can Vietnam make this transition toward renewable energy economical while unlocking growth? To find possible solutions for this dilemma, we undertook research to show how it could be possible.</p>
<h2>Showcasing the viability of economic renewables in Vietnam</h2>
<p>To illustrate the feasibility of Vietnam’s renewable-energy development, we chose two example provinces—Ba Ria-Vung Tau and Binh Dinh—that have the necessary criteria for workable renewable-energy generation. Ba Ria-Vung Tau offers great industrial demand and natural resource potential, making it ideal for RE100 at an industrial park, while Binh Dinh has high natural resource potential but less industrial demand, making it a suitable province to achieve RE50 penetration.</p>
<h3>Grid parity RE100 for manufacturers: Ba Ria-Vung Tau example</h3>
<p>We found that if DPPAs are allowed, projects at a Ba Ria-Vung Tau industrial park could be optimized, which in turn could reduce the levelized cost of energy (LCOE) to between $65 per megawatt-hour (MWh) to $80 per MWh (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/putting%20renewable%20energy%20within%20reach%20vietnams%20high%20stakes%20pivot/svgz-vietnamnetzero-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="When a direct power purchase agreement is allowed, 100 percent renewable energy can be achieved at a lower cost than grid price." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/putting%20renewable%20energy%20within%20reach%20vietnams%20high%20stakes%20pivot/svgz-vietnamnetzero-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>This could be achieved by taking the following steps:</p>
<p><em><strong>Quick wins by deploying transitional capacity</strong></em>. Vietnam currently has several transitional projects underway, driven by the uncertainty surrounding DPPAs and the low selling price of electricity to Vietnam Electricity (EVN) compared to previous FiT prices.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4c40a00b-823a-4c36-a499-523188e0db35"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4c40a00b-823a-4c36-a499-523188e0db35" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">As of June 2023, 59/85 transitional renewable-energy projects accepted a provisional price equal to just 50 percent of the ceiling price (which is already 20 to 30 percent lower than previous FiT prices); “List of 40 transitional renewable energy projects proposed a temporary price of 50% of price bracket, submitted to Ministry of Industry and Trade for approval of temporary price, signed PPA today,” CafeF, May 27, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Negotiations have the potential to achieve savings of 10 to 20 percent on capital expenditure compared to constructing new solar and onshore wind facilities. For instance, in the surrounding provinces of Ba Ria-Vung Tau, Chau Duc Industrial Park, and Xuyen Moc, onshore wind is currently stranded. Bringing these online would add a low cost of about 150 MW of renewable capacity to the power mix, a significant quick win.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6ab35677-4882-4e88-a99f-666de755dee8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6ab35677-4882-4e88-a99f-666de755dee8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“List of transitional projects: 42 MW out of 100 MW solar project in Chau Duc IP and 103 MW Xuyen Moc onshore wind project,” Ministry of Industry and Trade of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p><strong><em>Selling directly.</em></strong> DPPAs are an essential mechanism for the shift to renewable energy. DPPAs allow companies generating renewable energy to sell this energy directly to private companies or consumers, enabling these entities to access renewable energy quickly without waiting for the infrastructure of publicly available sources to improve. DPPAs also provide renewable-energy companies with the ability to scale their operations, making them more financially viable. In addition, DPPAs increase the likely bankability of projects by guaranteeing offtake, which reduces a project’s cost of capital and thus final LCOE.</p>
<p>Without DPPAs, offshore wind and utility-scale solar can’t be used to provide renewable energy within an industrial park: DPPAs are required to access renewable sources outside an industrial park, and for the park to achieve RE100, renewable-energy generators need to be able to sell clean electricity directly to private offtakers.</p>
<p><strong><em>Going big.</em></strong> Developers and investors need to think big and commit to developing multi-GW pipelines. We estimate that this action could reduce project risks, as well as lower capital expenditure by 5 to 15 percent and operating expenses by 10 to 20 percent. Developers could incentivize suppliers to invest locally in long-term, large-scale projects, creating win–win supplier partnerships. These could be boosted in three ways: first, by establishing a cost-efficient local-manufacturing ecosystem to support this multi-GW pipeline, enabled by volume discounts and the localization of components; second, by collaborating to develop local talent for the long term through partnerships with the National Innovation Centre, the Ba Ria-Vung Tau government, and foreign governments like Denmark<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fbcf316d-6f7c-4064-8030-708b1a603d67"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fbcf316d-6f7c-4064-8030-708b1a603d67" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Danish energy partnership programme between Denmark and Vietnam 2021–25 (DEPP III),” International Energy Agency, February 28, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span>; and third, by investing in self-performing operation and maintenance (O&M) capabilities, shifting from external O&M contractors to in-house ones.</p>
<p><strong><em>Embracing cutting-edge downstream green technology.</em></strong> According to our analysis, the cost of energy could be further cut by using the excess electricity produced during the sunniest and windiest times of day. For example, this surplus generation could be sold to the grid or used to produce green hydrogen and charge electric vehicles, all of which could be valuable depending on different market conditions.</p>
<p><strong><em>Capitalizing on green premium.</em></strong> We have observed that C&I customers, particularly RE100 companies, are potentially prepared to pay up to 10 percent green premiums for renewable energy in Vietnam, which would lead to a lower electricity cost for developers. If Vietnam cannot provide RE100, these customers will likely be happy to move to alternative markets for production.</p>
<h3>Grid Parity RE50 for a province: Binh Dinh example</h3>
<p>We believe that grid parity for RE50 is possible for the entire Binh Dinh province. This could be achieved through a number of levers, which would slash LCOE from the normal $100 per  MWh (approximate) to an optimized $85 per MWh or thereabouts (Exhibit 4). A number of actions could be taken to reach these goals.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/putting%20renewable%20energy%20within%20reach%20vietnams%20high%20stakes%20pivot/svgz-vietnamnetzero-ex4-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="By pulling cost reduction and revenue levers, 50 percent renewable energy can be achieved at a lower cost than grid price in 2030." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/putting%20renewable%20energy%20within%20reach%20vietnams%20high%20stakes%20pivot/svgz-vietnamnetzero-ex4-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h4>Stopping the waste: Investing in energy upgrades</h4>
<p>Grid congestion is a major problem in renewable-energy centers, including Binh Dinh. Some 110 kilovolt (kV) lines (such as Vinh Son-Hoai Nhon and Vinh Son-An Khe) are either degraded or congested (or both) after operating for about 30 years and are not designed to accommodate a renewable-energy mix.</p>
<p><strong><em>Additional grid investment </em></strong>would be required in Binh Dinh to increase its flexibility to provide significant renewable energy—although this could double the cost of transmission and distribution (T&D). However, we estimate that a grid upgrade could also lead to a reduction in T&D losses by about 10 percent (most of which come from transmission). In addition, total capital expenditures and operating expenditures could be reduced through a combination of cost reduction techniques, such as inventory optimization and negotiation with contractors based on past performances, leading to an additional 10 percent cost reduction.</p>
<p><strong><em>Extra financing support</em></strong> would be needed for a grid upgrade investment. This could include leveraging international green funds, such as the $15.5 billion Just Energy Transition Partnership (JETP) funds.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7cf625c5-108c-4aa3-bad3-c98bccd05201"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7cf625c5-108c-4aa3-bad3-c98bccd05201" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Political declaration on establishing the Just Energy Transition Partnership with Vietnam,” European Commission, December 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Private capital in construction and operations is another possible source of funding—consider, for instance, the Trungnam Group that has invested in and has been operating the $85 million 500 kV substations and transmission lines in Ninh Thuan.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bf5c3a19-97d6-474f-86c1-46599490290d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bf5c3a19-97d6-474f-86c1-46599490290d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Trungnam Group inaugurates solar power project,” Trungnam Group, October 12, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h4>Optimizing the system: Using the best energy mix in the best location</h4>
<p>An RE50 center is best placed in an area that has existing renewable-energy capacity with high potential for further capacity and existing solid infrastructure. Binh Dinh is well placed for solar and wind development that could supply significant renewable power and already has existing renewable-energy centers in Vinh Thanh, Tay Son, Nhon Hoi-Quy Nhon, and Phu My.</p>
<p>The best energy mix could be maximized in the following ways:</p>
<p><strong><em>Minimizing and standardizing design.</em></strong> Suppliers could minimize design through a design-to-value (DtV) approach, while developers could standardize “blocks” of modules and processes for rapid construction and repeatability—shrinking LCOE by around $1 per MWh, according to our analysis. This could unlock scale and lower the cost of multi-GW development portfolios.</p>
<p>For instance, with regard to solar, changing the back sheet material of photovoltaic modules from polyvinyl fluoride or polyvinylidene fluoride to flexible flat cable could reduce costs. In general, moving to materials that are easier to access could help cut down on cost and time for renewable-energy plants.</p>
<p>For onshore wind, our estimations show that DtV initiatives like special connectors and removing castings could lead to a 5 to 10 percent capital expenditure reduction.</p>
<p><strong><em>Operational excellence.</em></strong> Based on industry expert input, we believe that optimizing O&M could help lower LCOE by around $5 per MWh. For example, central control towers and remote operations could improve asset availability and reduce risk. Performance could be improved by real-time generation and relevant data analysis. Insights into the weather and its impact on plants, as well as fault detection, could help identify problem areas and enable proactive repairs. This data use, along with thermography-based hotspot detection, could cut down unplanned maintenance incidents by up to around 50 percent.</p>
<h2>The ‘and?’: How Vietnam’s public and private sector can make this happen</h2>
<p>The challenges may appear formidable, but we believe that Vietnam could solve its energy dilemma and secure its economic future through public- and private-sector collaboration. Ten crucial actions could be taken to reduce the cost of renewables, and by following a logical sequence of specific actions, a synchronized effort could realize economically viable RE100 and RE50 in the country.</p>
<h3>Key public-sector unlocks</h3>
<p>Six general best practices could unlock renewables:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Enable DPPAs to allow for off-site renewable-energy trades.</em> This could ensure renewable-energy bankability and profitability, for example, through net metering and open access. DPPAs would get rid of constraints—buyers could buy clean energy directly from private developers (that are outside consumers’ sites) rather than a mix of energy from EVN. This action could encourage developers to stay in, or enter, Vietnam.</li>
    <li><em>Commit to clear regulations and targets.</em> Regulation is required to create fairness within the industry and transparency for developers and would need to include the following:
    <ol>
        <li>revise and improve model PPAs on termination and curtailment compensation—for instance, where EVN is unable to purchase offtake energy</li>
        <li>create mechanisms to award new renewable-energy projects including site allocation and offtake price, particularly for offshore wind</li>
        <li>establish targets for the development of hydrogen and other alternative fuels, along with preferential policies for these industries</li>
    </ol>
    </li>
    <li><em>Invest in the grid.</em> Developers and investors could be attracted to new projects if the grid were updated to allow JETP projects and other investments. The ability of the private sector to participate in the grid development and operation may also make Vietnam more enticing to investors.</li>
    <li><em>Finalize negotiations with various Association of Southeast Asian Nation countries to export renewable energy.</em> The public sector could define the rules for request-for-proposal applications and government-to-government memorandums of understanding with nearby countries.</li>
    <li><em>Pilot RE100 industrial parks in leading “lighthouse” provinces.</em> Ambitious provincial leaders could take leading positions in renewables and attract FDI by encouraging the establishment of an RE100 industrial park. This would require collaboration by the provincial Ministry of Planning and Investment, Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, and central government agencies to attract both anchor renewable-energy developers and C&I customers.</li>
    <li><em>Introduce other key enablers.</em> When it comes to the execution phase, the government could consider putting in place other measures as soon as possible, such as a carbon tax and carbon market, thus incentivizing the adoption of renewables with their comparatively lower prices.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Bold moves from private-sector leaders</h3>
<p>Working in tandem with the public sector, players in the private sector can act immediately to seize the opportunity for growth. They could consider four big strategic decisions:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Developers commit to a multi-GW pipeline.</em> This could unlock supplier investment in the local value chain ecosystem and lower costs through economies of scale. In addition, it would likely incentivize local workforce development by local authorities.</li>
    <li><em>C&I customers commit to offtake through DPPAs.</em> C&I customers could guarantee demand and offtake, making initial RE100 projects immediately bankable—especially if they are willing to pay a green premium for 24/7 renewable electrons.</li>
    <li><em>Developers and suppliers reduce costs through standardized design.</em> Once developers have committed to a scale pipeline, they could standardize one optimized design across different sites, allowing rapid commissioning and lower costs.</li>
    <li><em>Developers and consumers embrace downstream green technology.</em> Developers could consider investing in (or creating) green technology to accelerate the renewable-energy journey—green hydrogen or electric-vehicle charging, for example. In addition, consumers could commit to green technology uptake, such as hydrogen offtake quantity and price.</li>
</ul>
<h3>The power of collaboration</h3>
<p>With the public and private sectors acting in tandem, Vietnam could achieve economical RE50 or RE100 across three time horizons. First, within the next 12 to 18 months, the country could establish the regulatory framework and commit to it, launching model PPA and DPPA pilots, accompanied by a public commitment to RE50 and RE100. Second, Vietnam could significantly increase its installed renewables capacity and continue to attract FDI within the next five to seven years. This could be achieved by transitioning to RE50 or RE100 in some provinces and enabling renewable-energy surplus outlets. Third, within a decade, the country could accelerate the net-zero commitment with widespread renewables across the country. With this, Vietnam could become the leading country in Southeast Asia with the highest-value renewable-energy economy.</p>
<hr>
<p>Vietnam’s urgent need to develop its renewable-energy generation to achieve the ambitious PDP8 goals can be met, even though the journey is beset with challenges. This could be achieved with the public sector paving the way by establishing clear regulations and reducing project risks for developers, and the private sector committing to a large-scale transition with multi-GW projects, creating a local renewable-energy ecosystem in Vietnam, and being prepared to pull cost reduction levers.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>Jonathan Deffarges</strong> and <strong>Hang Vu</strong> are consultants in McKinsey’s Hanoi office, where <strong><a href="/our-people/bruce-delteil">Bruce Delteil</a></strong> is a partner; <strong>Takuya Hata</strong> and <strong>Van Pham</strong> are consultants in the Ho Chi Minh office; <strong><a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b42fb84cb-b8db-4f40-b137-e2e4cf90c8c1%7d%40en">Suvojoy Sengupta</a></strong> is a partner in the Delhi office; and <strong>Kunal Tara</strong> is a partner in the Bangkok office.</p>

1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eVietnam\u0026rsquo;s long-awaited\u003c/strong\u003e Power Development Plan VIII (PDP8) has recently been approved, setting ambitious renewable-energy goals for 2030\u0026mdash;similar to the recommendations for Vietnam to embrace renewables set out in our 2019 article, \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/exploring-an-alternative-pathway-for-vietnams-energy-future\"\u003eExploring an alternative pathway for Vietnam\u0026rsquo;s energy future\u003c/a\u003e.\u0026rdquo; These goals are focused on boosting renewable energy while reducing the country\u0026rsquo;s reliance on coal. This presents Vietnam with a conundrum: its renewable-energy projects are not consistently bankable at present, held back by regulations and the market.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar authors]]\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, current market conditions present the country\u0026rsquo;s energy sector with a unique opportunity. Many manufacturers are avoiding investing solely in China by diversifying into neighboring countries to mitigate geopolitical risk, including into Vietnam.[[footnote 1]] To support this trend of incoming foreign direct investment (FDI), Vietnam could deploy more renewables to meet commercial and industrial (C\u0026amp;I) customers\u0026rsquo; increasing demand for renewables.[[footnote 2]] If it can seize this opportunity and successfully address the challenges that arise, Vietnam has the potential to become a regional champion for both installed renewable capacity and sustainable manufacturing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn part through the PDP8\u0026rsquo;s boost for renewable energy, Vietnam has committed to net zero by 2050 and, to achieve this, should rapidly increase its renewable-energy mix to decarbonize the power sector by around 78 percent.[[footnote 3]] Fortunately, Vietnam has huge renewable-energy potential, as it is the most naturally suited country in Southeast Asia to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/charting-a-path-for-vietnam-to-achieve-its-net-zero-goals\"\u003edevelop wind and solar energy\u003c/a\u003e, with the technical potential of 1,000 gigawatts (GW) (Exhibit 1). This immense opportunity for renewables capacity was explored in the \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/exploring-an-alternative-pathway-for-vietnams-energy-future\"\u003e2019 article\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;previously mentioned.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eYet, after an initial wave of (mostly solar) projects driven by favorable feed-in tariffs (FiTs), current renewable-energy projects are no longer consistently economically viable. Unless this situation changes, Vietnam\u0026rsquo;s net-zero ambitions\u0026mdash;as well as the PDP8\u0026rsquo;s goals\u0026mdash;are at risk, with market and regulatory constraints preventing this potential from being realized (Exhibit 2). Consider also that Vietnam\u0026rsquo;s neighbors might develop renewable energy faster, attracting international 100 percent renewable-energy (RE100) manufacturers at Vietnam\u0026rsquo;s expense. The time to ramp up renewable-energy production is now\u0026mdash;for the business opportunity as well as the country\u0026rsquo;s sustainability.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eHow can Vietnam achieve this? It needs to invest in, build, and integrate more solar and wind power to allow the country to provide 50 or 100 percent renewable energy (RE50/RE100) in an economically viable way\u0026mdash;thus making it more attractive to manufacturers, investors, and renewable-energy developers. In this article, we focus on feasible steps that energy stakeholders could take to achieve this goal and highlight how collaboration between the public and private sectors could help accelerate renewable-energy development (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;Our methodology\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eVietnam\u0026rsquo;s pivot to renewables: Embracing the path to leadership in sustainability\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf Vietnam cannot transition to renewables soon, it will likely face significant risks to its energy security, growth and development, and current economic base, as well as physical hazards from climate change\u0026mdash;this could come at Vietnam\u0026rsquo;s expense while its neighbors prosper. The risks, as described below, raise the stakes for the urgent deployment of renewables at scale.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEnergy insecurity and persistent blackouts\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith electricity demand increasing and extreme weather conditions affecting the country, renewable energy offers an independent source of energy security, not dependent on fossil-fuel imports. Recently, the country has faced electricity shortages and planned blackouts because of extreme heat, droughts, and hydropower plants reaching dangerously low water levels, for example, in industrial parks in northern provinces where large global manufacturers such as Samsung and Foxconn have facilities.[[footnote 4]] As a result, the government has instituted rolling blackouts (sometimes unannounced) across the country\u0026mdash;particularly in the north\u0026mdash;that have affected citizens, tourism, and industrial parks.[[footnote 5]] This is happening while the country\u0026rsquo;s abundant natural endowments of wind and sunlight remain underutilized.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eVietnam needs to unlock its renewable-energy development as quickly as possible to reach the government\u0026rsquo;s commitment to net zero by 2050 and the bold PDP8 goals, which aim for wind, solar, and other renewable sources (excluding hydropower) to cover at least 32 percent of the country\u0026rsquo;s energy needs by 2030.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSources of growth and development abandoning Vietnam\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany international companies are choosing Vietnam as they diversify from China, attracted by the country\u0026rsquo;s rapid economic growth and human capital abundance.[[footnote 7]] However, Vietnam is at risk of losing these actors\u0026rsquo; interest if it cannot meet their increased renewable-energy demands. Many of the world\u0026rsquo;s largest manufacturers have committed to 100 percent renewable energy for their operations (for example, those in the RE100 global initiative)[[footnote 8]]; these companies may not choose Vietnam if sufficient renewable power is not available. In addition, there are many global companies that don\u0026rsquo;t yet have existing operations in Vietnam\u0026mdash;were it able to provide RE100, the country could potentially attract more investments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eRisking Vietnam\u0026rsquo;s existing economic base\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf Vietnam does not implement renewables at scale now, it could jeopardize its current economic base, as manufacturers\u0026rsquo; products face carbon tariffs without clean energy.[[footnote 9]] For example, more than $10 billion of Vietnam\u0026rsquo;s export turnover from industries under carbon border tax schemes might be impacted by 2030. If other countries implement similar taxes, around an additional $20 billion in exports from those industries could be impacted. And if other manufacturing products under the same regulations are included, this could further put at least $200 billion in exports at risk.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePhysical hazards from climate change\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVietnam faces significant physical risk from climate change. Urban areas especially are exposed\u0026mdash;for example, the flood depth in Ho Chi Minh City could increase tenfold by 2050, and a 180 centimeter sea-level rise could put 66 percent of the city underwater. These climate change risks could cause 40 percent of the city to flood, and damage and associated losses could cost between $15 billion and $20 billion.[[footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eIf Vietnam doesn\u0026rsquo;t, its neighbors will\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVietnam\u0026rsquo;s lagging renewable-energy projects stand in stark contrast to its neighbors that have already started to make renewable energy economical. For instance, India has targeted 500 GW renewable energy capacity by 2030 and introduced the Electricity Act in 2003 that paved the way for open access and corporate power purchase agreements (PPAs).[[footnote 12]] Samsung is making India a smartphone manufacturing hub, and Foxconn is in discussion to launch a plant in Tamil Nadu.[[footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs another example, Malaysia has already launched virtual power purchase agreements (VPPAs) that have freed up consumers with more than 1 megawatt (MW) demand and has set targets for 70 percent renewables by 2050.[[footnote 14]] In contrast, at current tariffs in Vietnam, renewable-energy projects are often not consistently economical, and thus are viewed as unfavorable for developers.[[footnote 15]] The country has not yet allowed direct power purchase  agreements (DPPAs) nor instituted mechanisms (including auction mechanisms) that would pave the way for renewable-energy projects. Vietnam\u0026rsquo;s higher energy price and low renewable-energy penetration could lead to a financial burden for consumers and a potential loss of foreign investment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThen how can Vietnam make this transition toward renewable energy economical while unlocking growth? To find possible solutions for this dilemma, we undertook research to show how it could be possible.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eShowcasing the viability of economic renewables in Vietnam\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo illustrate the feasibility of Vietnam\u0026rsquo;s renewable-energy development, we chose two example provinces\u0026mdash;Ba Ria-Vung Tau and Binh Dinh\u0026mdash;that have the necessary criteria for workable renewable-energy generation. Ba Ria-Vung Tau offers great industrial demand and natural resource potential, making it ideal for RE100 at an industrial park, while Binh Dinh has high natural resource potential but less industrial demand, making it a suitable province to achieve RE50 penetration.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGrid parity RE100 for manufacturers: Ba Ria-Vung Tau example\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe found that if DPPAs are allowed, projects at a Ba Ria-Vung Tau industrial park could be optimized, which in turn could reduce the levelized cost of energy (LCOE) to between $65 per megawatt-hour (MWh) to $80 per MWh (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eThis could be achieved by taking the following steps:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eQuick wins by deploying transitional capacity\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e. Vietnam currently has several transitional projects underway, driven by the uncertainty surrounding DPPAs and the low selling price of electricity to Vietnam Electricity (EVN) compared to previous FiT prices.[[footnote 16]] Negotiations have the potential to achieve savings of 10 to 20 percent on capital expenditure compared to constructing new solar and onshore wind facilities. For instance, in the surrounding provinces of Ba Ria-Vung Tau, Chau Duc Industrial Park, and Xuyen Moc, onshore wind is currently stranded. Bringing these online would add a low cost of about 150 MW of renewable capacity to the power mix, a significant quick win.[[footnote 17]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eSelling directly.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e DPPAs are an essential mechanism for the shift to renewable energy. DPPAs allow companies generating renewable energy to sell this energy directly to private companies or consumers, enabling these entities to access renewable energy quickly without waiting for the infrastructure of publicly available sources to improve. DPPAs also provide renewable-energy companies with the ability to scale their operations, making them more financially viable. In addition, DPPAs increase the likely bankability of projects by guaranteeing offtake, which reduces a project\u0026rsquo;s cost of capital and thus final LCOE.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWithout DPPAs, offshore wind and utility-scale solar can\u0026rsquo;t be used to provide renewable energy within an industrial park: DPPAs are required to access renewable sources outside an industrial park, and for the park to achieve RE100, renewable-energy generators need to be able to sell clean electricity directly to private offtakers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eGoing big.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Developers and investors need to think big and commit to developing multi-GW pipelines. We estimate that this action could reduce project risks, as well as lower capital expenditure by 5 to 15 percent and operating expenses by 10 to 20 percent. Developers could incentivize suppliers to invest locally in long-term, large-scale projects, creating win\u0026ndash;win supplier partnerships. These could be boosted in three ways: first, by establishing a cost-efficient local-manufacturing ecosystem to support this multi-GW pipeline, enabled by volume discounts and the localization of components; second, by collaborating to develop local talent for the long term through partnerships with the National Innovation Centre, the Ba Ria-Vung Tau government, and foreign governments like Denmark[[footnote 18]]; and third, by investing in self-performing operation and maintenance (O\u0026amp;M) capabilities, shifting from external O\u0026amp;M contractors to in-house ones.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eEmbracing cutting-edge downstream green technology.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e According to our analysis, the cost of energy could be further cut by using the excess electricity produced during the sunniest and windiest times of day. For example, this surplus generation could be sold to the grid or used to produce green hydrogen and charge electric vehicles, all of which could be valuable depending on different market conditions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eCapitalizing on green premium.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e We have observed that C\u0026amp;I customers, particularly RE100 companies, are potentially prepared to pay up to 10 percent green premiums for renewable energy in Vietnam, which would lead to a lower electricity cost for developers. If Vietnam cannot provide RE100, these customers will likely be happy to move to alternative markets for production.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGrid Parity RE50 for a province: Binh Dinh example\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe believe that grid parity for RE50 is possible for the entire Binh Dinh province. This could be achieved through a number of levers, which would slash LCOE from the normal $100 per  MWh (approximate) to an optimized $85 per MWh or thereabouts (Exhibit 4). A number of actions could be taken to reach these goals.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003ch4\u003eStopping the waste: Investing in energy upgrades\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGrid congestion is a major problem in renewable-energy centers, including Binh Dinh. Some 110 kilovolt (kV) lines (such as Vinh Son-Hoai Nhon and Vinh Son-An Khe) are either degraded or congested (or both) after operating for about 30 years and are not designed to accommodate a renewable-energy mix.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eAdditional grid investment\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003ewould be required in Binh Dinh to increase its flexibility to provide significant renewable energy\u0026mdash;although this could double the cost of transmission and distribution (T\u0026amp;D). However, we estimate that a grid upgrade could also lead to a reduction in T\u0026amp;D losses by about 10 percent (most of which come from transmission). In addition, total capital expenditures and operating expenditures could be reduced through a combination of cost reduction techniques, such as inventory optimization and negotiation with contractors based on past performances, leading to an additional 10 percent cost reduction.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eExtra financing support\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e would be needed for a grid upgrade investment. This could include leveraging international green funds, such as the $15.5 billion Just Energy Transition Partnership (JETP) funds.[[footnote 19]] Private capital in construction and operations is another possible source of funding\u0026mdash;consider, for instance, the Trungnam Group that has invested in and has been operating the $85 million 500 kV substations and transmission lines in Ninh Thuan.[[footnote 20]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eOptimizing the system: Using the best energy mix in the best location\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn RE50 center is best placed in an area that has existing renewable-energy capacity with high potential for further capacity and existing solid infrastructure. Binh Dinh is well placed for solar and wind development that could supply significant renewable power and already has existing renewable-energy centers in Vinh Thanh, Tay Son, Nhon Hoi-Quy Nhon, and Phu My.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe best energy mix could be maximized in the following ways:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eMinimizing and standardizing design.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Suppliers could minimize design through a design-to-value (DtV) approach, while developers could standardize \u0026ldquo;blocks\u0026rdquo; of modules and processes for rapid construction and repeatability\u0026mdash;shrinking LCOE by around $1 per MWh, according to our analysis. This could unlock scale and lower the cost of multi-GW development portfolios.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor instance, with regard to solar, changing the back sheet material of photovoltaic modules from polyvinyl fluoride or polyvinylidene fluoride to flexible flat cable could reduce costs. In general, moving to materials that are easier to access could help cut down on cost and time for renewable-energy plants.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor onshore wind, our estimations show that DtV initiatives like special connectors and removing castings could lead to a 5 to 10 percent capital expenditure reduction.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eOperational excellence.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e Based on industry expert input, we believe that optimizing O\u0026amp;M could help lower LCOE by around $5 per MWh. For example, central control towers and remote operations could improve asset availability and reduce risk. Performance could be improved by real-time generation and relevant data analysis. Insights into the weather and its impact on plants, as well as fault detection, could help identify problem areas and enable proactive repairs. This data use, along with thermography-based hotspot detection, could cut down unplanned maintenance incidents by up to around 50 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThe \u0026lsquo;and?\u0026rsquo;: How Vietnam\u0026rsquo;s public and private sector can make this happen\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe challenges may appear formidable, but we believe that Vietnam could solve its energy dilemma and secure its economic future through public- and private-sector collaboration. Ten crucial actions could be taken to reduce the cost of renewables, and by following a logical sequence of specific actions, a synchronized effort could realize economically viable RE100 and RE50 in the country.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eKey public-sector unlocks\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSix general best practices could unlock renewables:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEnable DPPAs to allow for off-site renewable-energy trades.\u003c/em\u003e This could ensure renewable-energy bankability and profitability, for example, through net metering and open access. DPPAs would get rid of constraints\u0026mdash;buyers could buy clean energy directly from private developers (that are outside consumers\u0026rsquo; sites) rather than a mix of energy from EVN. This action could encourage developers to stay in, or enter, Vietnam.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eCommit to clear regulations and targets.\u003c/em\u003e Regulation is required to create fairness within the industry and transparency for developers and would need to include the following:\n    \u003col\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003erevise and improve model PPAs on termination and curtailment compensation\u0026mdash;for instance, where EVN is unable to purchase offtake energy\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003ecreate mechanisms to award new renewable-energy projects including site allocation and offtake price, particularly for offshore wind\u003c/li\u003e\n        \u003cli\u003eestablish targets for the development of hydrogen and other alternative fuels, along with preferential policies for these industries\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003c/ol\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eInvest in the grid.\u003c/em\u003e Developers and investors could be attracted to new projects if the grid were updated to allow JETP projects and other investments. The ability of the private sector to participate in the grid development and operation may also make Vietnam more enticing to investors.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFinalize negotiations with various Association of Southeast Asian Nation countries to export renewable energy.\u003c/em\u003e The public sector could define the rules for request-for-proposal applications and government-to-government memorandums of understanding with nearby countries.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003ePilot RE100 industrial parks in leading \u0026ldquo;lighthouse\u0026rdquo; provinces.\u003c/em\u003e Ambitious provincial leaders could take leading positions in renewables and attract FDI by encouraging the establishment of an RE100 industrial park. This would require collaboration by the provincial Ministry of Planning and Investment, Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, and central government agencies to attract both anchor renewable-energy developers and C\u0026amp;I customers.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIntroduce other key enablers.\u003c/em\u003e When it comes to the execution phase, the government could consider putting in place other measures as soon as possible, such as a carbon tax and carbon market, thus incentivizing the adoption of renewables with their comparatively lower prices.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eBold moves from private-sector leaders\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWorking in tandem with the public sector, players in the private sector can act immediately to seize the opportunity for growth. They could consider four big strategic decisions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDevelopers commit to a multi-GW pipeline.\u003c/em\u003e This could unlock supplier investment in the local value chain ecosystem and lower costs through economies of scale. In addition, it would likely incentivize local workforce development by local authorities.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eC\u0026amp;I customers commit to offtake through DPPAs.\u003c/em\u003e C\u0026amp;I customers could guarantee demand and offtake, making initial RE100 projects immediately bankable\u0026mdash;especially if they are willing to pay a green premium for 24/7 renewable electrons.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDevelopers and suppliers reduce costs through standardized design.\u003c/em\u003e Once developers have committed to a scale pipeline, they could standardize one optimized design across different sites, allowing rapid commissioning and lower costs.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDevelopers and consumers embrace downstream green technology.\u003c/em\u003e Developers could consider investing in (or creating) green technology to accelerate the renewable-energy journey\u0026mdash;green hydrogen or electric-vehicle charging, for example. In addition, consumers could commit to green technology uptake, such as hydrogen offtake quantity and price.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe power of collaboration\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith the public and private sectors acting in tandem, Vietnam could achieve economical RE50 or RE100 across three time horizons. First, within the next 12 to 18 months, the country could establish the regulatory framework and commit to it, launching model PPA and DPPA pilots, accompanied by a public commitment to RE50 and RE100. Second, Vietnam could significantly increase its installed renewables capacity and continue to attract FDI within the next five to seven years. This could be achieved by transitioning to RE50 or RE100 in some provinces and enabling renewable-energy surplus outlets. Third, within a decade, the country could accelerate the net-zero commitment with widespread renewables across the country. With this, Vietnam could become the leading country in Southeast Asia with the highest-value renewable-energy economy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVietnam\u0026rsquo;s urgent need to develop its renewable-energy generation to achieve the ambitious PDP8 goals can be met, even though the journey is beset with challenges. This could be achieved with the public sector paving the way by establishing clear regulations and reducing project risks for developers, and the private sector committing to a large-scale transition with multi-GW projects, creating a local renewable-energy ecosystem in Vietnam, and being prepared to pull cost reduction levers.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":true},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-10-02T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;Gartner survey reveals 33% of supply chain leaders moved business out of China or plan to by 2023,\u0026rdquo; are many paths\u003c/strong\u003e to achieving economic 50 or 100 percent renewable energy (RE50/RE100) in specific contexts and use cases in Vietnam by 2030. We use RE100 as a target, given that many commercial and industrial customers (for example, the companies in the RE100 global initiative) are demanding 24/7 renewable power.[[footnote 1]] This article outlines particular steps that we believe could be the most impactful and that are feasible from a technology and supply chain perspective in aggregate, based on current outlooks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo arrive at this pathway, we used proprietary optimization models and data from McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Green Power Procurement Optimizer tool, Hydrogen Insights, and the Strategy \u0026amp; Corporate Finance Practice to evaluate about 100 cost-reduction levers to minimize Vietnam\u0026rsquo;s overall cost of electricity generation. In this optimization, we accounted for national and regional constraints such as (but not exclusively) technical maximum for wind- and solar-power generation, maximum pumped hydro-energy storage potential in each province, land availability for renewable-energy sites, and planned renewable-energy capacity for each technology in Vietnam\u0026rsquo;s Power Development Plan VIII.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe did not account for the nonmonetary benefits achieved by RE50/RE100, such as reduced air pollution, greater health benefits, and reduced physical climate risks through decarbonization. These benefits are significant for Vietnam.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis outcome is not a forecast but rather a road map that illustrates how national ministries, provinces, and corporate stakeholders could collaborate across different sectors to decrease the cost of electricity by 2030 and increase penetration of renewables.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe consider the exploration of this road map to be valuable for two reasons: first, it demonstrates that Vietnam has the potential to deploy renewables at a greater scale\u0026mdash;economically\u0026mdash;than it currently does, and second, the road map lays out specific steps that public- and private-sector stakeholders could take to make this happen.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Our methodology"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;How RE100
